classifications.note: Definition: 1 eV = kinetic energy of electron accelerated through 1 V, 1 eV = 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ J, Elementary charge: e = 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, For any charge: ΔE = qΔV in eV when q in elementary charges

principles.statement: The electron volt is defined through fundamental relationships: Basic Definition: 1 eV = kinetic energy gained by electron (charge e = 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) accelerated through 1 V potential difference; Mathematical: 1 eV = e × 1 V = 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ J. General Formula: For any charge q moving through ΔV: Energy change = qΔV; In eV: divide by e, so E(eV) = (q/e) × ΔV; For n electrons: E(eV) = n × ΔV. Physical Significance: Natural unit for atomic physics; Atomic energy levels typically eV scale; Chemical bonds: 1-10 eV range; Ionization energies: eV scale. Conversion Factors: 1 eV = 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ J; 1 J = 6.242 × 10¹⁸ eV; Remember: eV is energy unit, not potential unit. Multiples and Submultiples: meV (milli-eV): atomic vibrations; eV: atomic transitions; keV (kilo-eV): X-rays, inner electrons; MeV (mega-eV): nuclear reactions; GeV (giga-eV): particle physics; TeV (tera-eV): high-energy physics. Temperature Equivalence: 1 eV ≈ 11,604 K; Room temperature ≈ 1/40 eV; Relates to thermal energy kT. Practical Calculation: Electron through V volts gains V eV; Proton through V volts gains V eV (same charge magnitude); Doubling voltage doubles energy in eV.
principles.application: Calculate energy in eV for charged particles. Convert between eV and joules accurately. Apply eV definition to various charge types. Use eV multiples for different energy scales. Relate eV to temperature scales. Solve basic acceleration problems.
principles.example: Calculate energy gained by electron through 500 V. Convert 2.5 eV to joules. Determine how many eV for proton through 1 kV.
principles.analogy: Like using 'light-years' for astronomical distances instead of kilometers - the electron volt is the 'natural ruler' for atomic world energies, where joules would be as impractical as millimeters for measuring interstellar distances

worked_examples.title: Basic Electron Acceleration
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the kinetic energy in eV and joules for an electron accelerated from rest through 100 V.

step_by_step.explanation: Energy in eV = voltage difference = 100 eV
Both methods give same result: 100 eV = 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁷ J

worked_examples.final_answer: Kinetic energy = 100 eV = 1.60 × 10⁻¹⁷ J; Simple relationship: voltage directly gives energy in eV for electrons

worked_examples.title: Proton Energy Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A proton is accelerated through 500 V. Calculate its kinetic energy in eV and joules.

step_by_step.explanation: Same energy in eV, but different speed due to mass difference

worked_examples.final_answer: Kinetic energy = 500 eV = 8.01 × 10⁻¹⁷ J; Same energy in eV as electron for same voltage, but different velocities

principles.statement: Electron volt multiples define characteristic energy scales: meV Range (10⁻³ eV): Atomic vibrations and phonons; Thermal energy at cryogenic temperatures; Superconductivity energy gaps. eV Range (1-10³ eV): Atomic energy levels and transitions; Chemical bond energies (1-10 eV); Visible photons (1.6-3.3 eV); Ionization energies (4-25 eV for atoms). keV Range (10³-10⁶ eV): X-ray photons; Inner electron binding energies; Medical imaging energies; Electron microscopy. MeV Range (10⁶-10⁹ eV): Nuclear energy levels; Gamma rays; Nuclear binding energies (~8 MeV/nucleon); Particle rest energies (electron 0.511 MeV). GeV Range (10⁹-10¹² eV): Proton rest energy (0.938 GeV); Particle physics resonances; Cosmic ray energies; Large accelerator scales. TeV Range (10¹² eV+): Frontier particle physics; LHC collision energies; Ultra-high energy cosmic rays. Temperature Equivalence: E = kT where k = 8.617 × 10⁻⁵ eV/K; 1 eV ≈ 11,604 K; Room temperature (300 K) ≈ 0.026 eV. Wavelength Relation: For photons: E(eV) = 1240/λ(nm); Visible light: 400-700 nm ↔ 3.1-1.8 eV; Useful for quick conversions. Mass-Energy: E = mc²; Electron: 0.511 MeV; Proton: 938.3 MeV; Neutron: 939.6 MeV; Atomic mass unit: 931.5 MeV.

principles.analogy: Like using different distance units for different scales - millimeters for precision engineering, meters for rooms, kilometers for travel, light-years for astronomy - each eV multiple is perfectly sized for its physical domain

principles.statement: Electron volt units find diverse applications: Atomic Physics: Hydrogen ground state: -13.6 eV; Ionization energies: 4-25 eV; Spectral lines: eV differences; Photoelectric effect: work functions 2-6 eV. Semiconductor Physics: Band gaps: Si 1.1 eV, Ge 0.67 eV, GaAs 1.43 eV; LED colors determined by band gap; Transistor operation energies; Solar cell thresholds. Nuclear Physics: Nuclear binding: ~8 MeV/nucleon; Gamma ray energies: keV-MeV; Fission fragments: ~200 MeV total; Fusion reactions: MeV products. Particle Physics: Electron: 0.511 MeV; Muon: 105.7 MeV; Proton: 938.3 MeV; W/Z bosons: ~80-91 GeV; Higgs: 125 GeV; LHC: 13 TeV collisions. Plasma Physics: Temperature in eV: kT conversion; Fusion plasmas: 10-20 keV; Solar corona: 100-200 eV; Industrial plasmas: 1-10 eV. Astrophysics: Stellar fusion: keV energies; Cosmic rays: GeV-TeV; Cosmic microwave background: 0.00023 eV; Solar spectrum peak: 1.4 eV. Measurement Techniques: Photoelectron spectroscopy; Mass spectrometry; Calorimetry in particle detectors; Semiconductor detectors. Device Applications: PMT and photodiode thresholds; Radiation detector energies; Accelerator design specifications; Laser and LED specifications.

summary: The electron volt (eV) is defined as the kinetic energy gained by an electron accelerated through a potential difference of one volt, equal to 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ joules. This unit provides a natural energy scale for atomic and subatomic processes where joules are impractically large. Key relationships include: E(eV) = qΔV/e for any charge, photon energy E(eV) = 1240/λ(nm), temperature equivalence 1 eV ≈ 11,604 K, and mass-energy E = mc² with electron mass 0.511 MeV and proton mass 938.3 MeV. Common multiples are meV (atomic vibrations), eV (atomic transitions), keV (X-rays), MeV (nuclear processes), GeV (particle masses), and TeV (collider energies). Applications span atomic physics (energy levels 1-100 eV), semiconductor devices (band gaps 0.1-3 eV), nuclear physics (binding energies ~8 MeV/nucleon), and particle physics (rest masses MeV-GeV scale). The electron volt serves as the fundamental energy currency across modern physics, enabling clear communication and calculation across diverse subfields from condensed matter to cosmology.
